A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → ∀ (a b : M), f a = f b
name: MDifferentiable.apply_eq_of_compactSpace
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant, i.e., the preimage of any set under a holomorphically differentiable function is an open set.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : I.Boundaryless] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → IsLocallyConstant f
name: MDifferentiable.isLocallyConstant
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant, i.e., the preimage of any set under a holomorphically differentiable function is an open set.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] (f : ℂ → E) (c : ℂ),
  (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

Integral closures are all isomorphic to each other.

type:
(R : Type u_1) →
  (A : Type u_2) →
    (B : Type u_3) →
      [inst : CommRing R] →
        [inst_1 : CommRing A] →
          [inst_2 : CommRing B] →
            [inst_3 : Algebra R B] →
              [inst_4 : Algebra A B] →
                [inst_5 : IsIntegralClosure A R B] →
                  (A' : Type u_4) →
                    [inst_6 : CommRing A'] →
                      [inst_7 : Algebra A' B] →
                        [inst_8 : IsIntegralClosure A' R B] →
                          [inst_9 : Algebra R A] →
                            [inst_10 : Algebra R A'] →
                              [inst_11 : IsScalarTower R A B] → [inst_12 : IsScalarTower R A' B] → A ≃ₐ[R] A'
name: IsIntegralClosure.equiv
docString: Integral closures are all isomorphic to each other.

For any continuous real-valued function on a closed interval, it is uniformly approximated by polynomials.

type: ∀ (a b : ℝ) (f : C(↑(Set.Icc a b), ℝ)), f ∈ (polynomialFunctions (Set.Icc a b)).topologicalClosure
name: continuousMap_mem_polynomialFunctions_closure
docString: For any continuous real-valued function on a closed interval, it is uniformly approximated by polynomials.

This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : FiniteDimensional ℝ E]
  {F : Type u_2} [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ℝ F] [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F]
  [inst_6 : MeasurableSpace E] [inst_7 : BorelSpace E] {f : E → F} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure E} {U : Set E},
  IsOpen U →
    MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f U μ →
      (∀ (g : E → ℝ), ContDiff ℝ ⊤ g → HasCompactSupport g → tsupport g ⊆ U → ∫ (x : E), g x • f x ∂μ = 0) →
        ∀ᵐ (x : E) ∂μ, x ∈ U → f x = 0
name: IsOpen.ae_eq_zero_of_integral_contDiff_smul_eq_zero
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` is locally integrable on an open subset `U` of a finite-dimensional real manifold, and if the integral of `f` multiplied by any smooth function that has compact support within `U` is zero, then the function `f` equals zero almost everywhere in `U`. Here, "almost everywhere" means that the set of points where the function does not equal zero has a measure of zero. The smooth function with compact support is differentiable to any order and is zero outside a compact set. The condition about the integral being zero effectively ensures that `f` and the smooth function are orthogonal in terms of the L^2 inner product, which is the integral of their product.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → IsLocallyConstant f
name: MDifferentiable.isLocallyConstant
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isClosed_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all closed sets, then it is zero
almost everwhere.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f → IsCompact k → MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    ∀ {k : Set X}, IsCompact k → ∃ u, IsOpen u ∧ k ⊆ u ∧ MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f u
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_nhds_isCompact
docString:
If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

Any continuous function on compact Hausdorff spaces is a closed map.

type: ∀ {X Y : CompHaus} (f : X ⟶ Y), IsClosedMap ⇑f
name: CompHaus.isClosedMap
docString: Any continuous function on compact Hausdorff spaces is a closed map.

If a function is locally integrable on a compact set, then it is integrable on that set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {s : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn f s → IsCompact s → MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f s
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrableOn.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable on a compact set, then it is integrable on that set.

A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts μ], Continuous f → HasCompactSupport f → MeasureTheory.Integrable f
name: Continuous.integrable_of_hasCompactSupport
docString: A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

If a function is integrable, then the integral of its truncated versions converges to the
integral of the whole function.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {f : α → ℝ},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    Filter.Tendsto (fun A => ∫ (x : α), ProbabilityTheory.truncation f A x ∂μ) Filter.atTop (nhds (∫ (x : α), f x ∂μ))
name: ProbabilityTheory.tendsto_integral_truncation
docString:
If a function is integrable, then the integral of its truncated versions converges to the
integral of the whole function.

The integrals along a decreasing approximating sequence to the indicator of a closed set
tend to the measure of the closed set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : HasOuterApproxClosed X] {F : Set X} (hF : IsClosed F)
  [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X)
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasure μ],
  Filter.Tendsto (fun n => ∫⁻ (x : X), ↑((IsClosed.apprSeq hF n) x) ∂μ) Filter.atTop (nhds (↑↑μ F))
name: HasOuterApproxClosed.tendsto_lintegral_apprSeq
docString:
The integrals along a decreasing approximating sequence to the indicator of a closed set
tend to the measure of the closed set.

The integral closure of R in an R-algebra A.

type: (R : Type u_1) → (A : Type u_2) → [inst : CommRing R] → [inst_1 : CommRing A] → [inst_2 : Algebra R A] → Subalgebra R A
name: integralClosure
docString: The integral closure of R in an R-algebra A.

If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero
docString:
If an integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space, then
it is zero almost everwhere.

The measure of a closed set is at most the integral of any function in a decreasing
approximating sequence to the indicator of the set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : HasOuterApproxClosed X] {F : Set X} (hF : IsClosed F)
  [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X) (n : ℕ),
  ↑↑μ F ≤ ∫⁻ (x : X), ↑((IsClosed.apprSeq hF n) x) ∂μ
name: HasOuterApproxClosed.measure_le_lintegral
docString:
The measure of a closed set is at most the integral of any function in a decreasing
approximating sequence to the indicator of the set.

In a locally compact space, any integrable function can be approximated by compactly supported
continuous functions, version in terms of `∫⁻`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_2 : T4Space α] [inst_3 : BorelSpace α]
  {E : Type u_2} [inst_4 : NormedAddCommGroup E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} [inst_5 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_6 : WeaklyLocallyCompactSpace α] [inst_7 : MeasureTheory.Measure.Regular μ] {f : α → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    ∀ {ε : ENNReal},
      ε ≠ 0 → ∃ g, HasCompactSupport g ∧ ∫⁻ (x : α), ↑‖f x - g x‖₊ ∂μ ≤ ε ∧ Continuous g ∧ MeasureTheory.Integrable g
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.exists_hasCompactSupport_lintegral_sub_le
docString:
In a locally compact space, any integrable function can be approximated by compactly supported
continuous functions, version in terms of `∫⁻`.

A constant function is uniformly integrable.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} {ι : Type u_3} {m : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α)
  [inst : NormedAddCommGroup β] {p : ENNReal} {g : α → β},
  1 ≤ p → p ≠ ⊤ → MeasureTheory.Memℒp g p → MeasureTheory.UnifIntegrable (fun x => g) p μ
name: MeasureTheory.unifIntegrable_const
docString: A constant function is uniformly integrable.

Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

type: ∀ {c w : ℂ} {R : ℝ}, w ∈ Metric.ball c R → (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - w)⁻¹) = 2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I
name: circleIntegral.integral_sub_inv_of_mem_ball
docString: Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℝ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {β : Type u_3}
  [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_4 : MeasurableSpace β] [inst_5 : BorelSpace β] [inst_6 : SigmaCompactSpace β]
  [inst_7 : T2Space β] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure β} {f : β → E},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    (∀ (s : Set β), IsCompact s → ∫ (x : β) in s, f x ∂μ = 0) → f =ᶠ[MeasureTheory.Measure.ae μ] 0
name: MeasureTheory.ae_eq_zero_of_forall_set_integral_isCompact_eq_zero'
docString:
If a locally integrable function has zero integral on all compact sets in a sigma-compact space,
then it is zero almost everwhere.

The integrals of thickened indicators of a closed set against a finite measure tend to the
measure of the closed set if the thickening radii tend to zero.

type:
∀ {Ω : Type u_2} [inst : MeasurableSpace Ω] [inst_1 : PseudoEMetricSpace Ω] [inst_2 : OpensMeasurableSpace Ω]
  (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure Ω) [inst_3 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasure μ] {F : Set Ω},
  IsClosed F →
    ∀ {δs : ℕ → ℝ} (δs_pos : ∀ (n : ℕ), 0 < δs n),
      Filter.Tendsto δs Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto (fun n => ∫⁻ (ω : Ω), ↑((thickenedIndicator (_ : 0 < δs n) F) ω) ∂μ) Filter.atTop (nhds (↑↑μ F))
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_lintegral_thickenedIndicator_of_isClosed
docString:
The integrals of thickened indicators of a closed set against a finite measure tend to the
measure of the closed set if the thickening radii tend to zero.

A partial homeomorphism is continuous at any point of its source

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] (e : PartialHomeomorph X Y)
  {x : X}, x ∈ e.source → ContinuousAt (↑e) x
name: PartialHomeomorph.continuousAt
docString: A partial homeomorphism is continuous at any point of its source
